questions.text: A 60-year-old man with hemiplegia is brought to the OPD for a follow-up visit. He suffered from a stroke 2 months ago. On examination, he was found to have slurred speech and a positive Babinski sign. Which other examination findings are expected to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given patient has slurred speech and a positive Babinski sign, which is suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion (UMN lesion). Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are a feature of UMN lesions.

The distal muscle groups are affected more than the proximal muscles and the axial muscles are spared (as the anterior corticospinal tracts supplying the axial muscles have bilateral representation) in UMN lesions. Axial muscles are involved when the lesion is severe or bilateral.

Hypertonia in the form of spasticity is seen in the upper motor neuron lesions. Fasciculations and hypotonia are features of lower motor neuron lesions.

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hypertonia is false?

choices.text: Rigidity is present throughout the range of motion
Spasticity predominantly affects the extensors of upper limb
Rigidity affects flexors and extensors equally

questions.solution:
Spasticity predominantly affects the antigravity muscles - flexors in the upper limb and extensors in the lower limb.

Spasticity Rigidity
Seen in lesions of pyramidal tracts Seen in lesions of the extrapyramidal tracts such as rubrospinal and vestibulospinal tracts
Velocity dependent - More noticeable with fast movements Present throughout range of motion without change in intensity
Clasp-knife phenomenon - sudden release after reaching maximum Lead pipe or plastic stiffness
Predominantly affects antigravity muscles Affects flexors and extensors equally

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with pseudobulbar palsy?
questions.solution:
Jaw jerk is brisk in pseudobulbar palsy.

Bilateral corticobulbar lesions produce pseudobulbar palsy. This condition is characterized by dysarthria, dysphagia, dysphonia, emotional lability, bilateral facial weakness, and brisk jaw jerk.

Damage to lower motor neurons of the cranial nerves in the brainstem is called bulbar palsy. Depressed jaw jerk is seen in bulbar palsy.

Pseudobulbar palsy is analogous to UMN lesions exhibiting hyperreflexia. Bulbar palsy is analogous to LMN lesions exhibiting hyporeflexia.

questions.text: All of the following drugs have to be stopped before a lumbar puncture, except:
questions.solution:
Aspirin and other NSAIDs can be continued in a patient who is scheduled to undergo a lumbar puncture (LP). These drugs have not shown an increased risk of developing spinal hematomas. Hence an LP can be performed in patients receiving these drugs.

Options A and B: Abciximab and eptifibatide are Gp IIb/ IIIa inhibitors. Platelet aggregation remains abnormal following the discontinuation of these drugs. LP, spinal and epidural procedures must be avoided until the platelet function is normal.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor. LP should be avoided in patients receiving this drug due to the risk of developing epidural or spinal hematomas. Other factor Xa inhibitors, namely, fondaparinux and apixaban must also be held prior to LP, spinal and epidural procedures.

questions.text: A pathologist received a blood-tinged CSF sample for evaluation. The sample was subjected to centrifugation and the following finding was observed. What is the least likely differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows xanthochromatic CSF on centrifugation. This is unlikely with a traumatic tap. A traumatic tap has clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation.

Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the drawn CSF sample. In such situations, centrifugation of the sample distinguishes the two.

  • Clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation supports a traumatic tap.
  • Xanthochromatic supernatant suggests SAH.

Xanthochromatic supernatant may be present in the following conditions:

  • In Liver disease, due to elevated bilirubin levels.
  • When CSF protein concentration is elevated.
  • In subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), RBCs are present in the CSF long enough for them to undergo lysis. This releases hemoglobin which is converted to bilirubin, thus staining the CSF yellow.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with nausea, fever, and neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture is ordered. All of the following are effective strategies to prevent post-lumbar puncture headache in this patient, except:

choices.text: Insertion of a needle with bevel pointed upwards
Replacement of stylet prior to removal of the needle

questions.solution:
The use of a 22 gauge needle (or smaller) can reduce the incidence of post-dural headache after lumbar puncture.

Effective strategies that reduce the incidence of PDPH include:

  • Use of small-diameter needle (22-gauge or smaller)
  • Use of atraumatic needle (Sprotte and others)
  • Replacement of stylet prior to removal of the needle
  • Insertion of a needle with bevel oriented in a cephalad to caudad direction (when using a stranded needle) 

Ineffective strategies:

  • Bed rest (up to 4h) following LP
  • Supplemental fluids
  • Minimizing the volume of spinal fluid removed
  • Immediate mobilization following LP

The customary practice of remaining in a recumbent position post-LP is unnecessary. Studies have shown no benefit in terms of reducing the incidence of headaches.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with sudden onset speech difficulty, tremors, and difficulty in walking. He is noted to have a wide stepping gait. He is a known hypertensive but is not adherent to treatment. Where is the lesion most likely to be seen on neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of cerebellar ataxia, hence the lesion is most likely to be seen in the cerebellum. Cerebellar ataxia can be caused due to an acute vascular event such as infarction or hemorrhage.

Wide stepping gait, a broad-based unstable gait is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. Few other notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness

A few of the cerebellar signs include:

  • Dysdiadokinesia / dysmetria
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor
  • Speech - slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency ward following an acute episode of inability to move his lower limbs. Examination findings are given below. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate for this patient?
  • Lower Limbs:
    • Reduced power
    • Reduced tone
    • Absent reflexes
    • Negative Babinski reflex
  • Upper Limbs:
    • Normal power
    • Normal tone
    • 2+ Reflexes
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute paraparesis. This is caused most commonly by an intraspinal lesion. A negative Babinski reflex and flaccidity are suggestive of a lower motor neuron lesion. Hence, the most appropriate among the given investigations for acute paraparesis with LMN signs is a spinal MRI.

Spinal causes of acute onset paraparesis include:

  • Injury to the spinal cord
  • Thrombosis of anterior vertebral artery
  • Hematomyelia
  • Prolapsed intervertebral disc

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate was >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do?
questions.solution:
Ruling out glycemic extremes is the first step in the evaluation of this patient who is in a coma as most of the causes of coma are metabolic in origin and with appropriate treatment are completely reversible.

In this elderly patient, with no other relevant history, the most likely cause of coma is diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state, or even hypoglycemia (which may present with hypertension).

Other options :

The patient presents with tachycardia which is not a sign of raised intracranial pressure(bradycardia, altered respiratory pattern, raised systolic blood pressure) and hence starting iv mannitol (option 3) to reduce intracranial pressure or doing a CT (option 4) to rule out intracranial space-occupying lesion is not required.

The patient is a known case of hypertension which may cause hypertensive encephalopathy due to cerebral edema and would present with a similar history and signs of raised intracranial pressure giving antihypertensive (option 2)  medications would treat the condition but it is not the first step as metabolic causes are more common and have to be addressed first. 

Coma is defined as a deep sleep-like state from which the patient cannot be aroused.Coma could be due to:

  • Metabolic and toxic encephalopathies, where brain imaging will be normal
  • Meningitis syndromes
  • Diseases with prominent focal signs like stroke, or hemorrhage

Urgent intervention is needed to prevent further brain damage. It is done by providing supplemental oxygen, intravenous thiamine (at least 100 mg), and intravenous 50% dextrose in water (25 g) empirically. It is crucial to measure baseline serum glucose levels before administering glucose.

The initial examination includes evaluating the general appearance,vitals, breath sounds, response to stimulation, pupil size and responsiveness, and any abnormal posturing or movements. In trauma cases, the neck should be stabilized until ruling out cervical spine fracture. Airway protection and intravenous access is necessary. 

Immediate therapeutic intervention should be done for hypotension, significant hypertension, bradycardia, arrhythmias affecting blood pressure or marked hyperthermia. Signs of meningeal irritation or fever indicate the need for urgent lumbar puncture. Fundus examination for papilledema and a CT scan of the brain should be performed prior to lumbar puncture in comatose patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of autonomic storm?
questions.solution:
Brain injury is the most common cause of autonomic storm and typically follows severe head trauma and postresuscitation anoxic-ischemic brain injury.

An autonomic storm is an acute state of sustained sympathetic surge which can cause alterations in BP and heart rate, body temperature, respiration, and sweating.

Other causes include:

  • Spinal cord injury
  • Drugs and toxins (phenylpropanolamine, cocaine, amphetamines, and TCA's; tetanus; and less often, botulinum toxin)
  • Autonomic neuropathy
  • Chemodectomas (e.g., pheochromocytoma).
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome can produce a moderate autonomic storm.

questions.text: What is the minimum Glasgow coma scale-pupils score for a head injury?
questions.solution:
The GCS-P score allows a minimum score of 1. 

The Glasgow coma scale – pupils score (GCS-P) was described in response to the wish for a single index combining the coma scale with pupillary reactivity as a reflection of brainstem function. Its possible values range from 1 to 15, reflecting an extended range of severity, and may be particularly useful in relating to prognosis.

The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the pupil reactivity score (PRS) from the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) total score:

GCS-P = GCS - PRS

The minimum score in GCS is 3.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident while driving a motorcycle. During the evaluation, the patient opens his eyes in response to voice and says inappropriate words. He is unable to move his right arm but extends his left arm when a painful stimulus is applied to his right arm. What is the GCS score of this patient?
questions.solution:
The GCS score of the patient described is 8 (E3 V3 M2).

In the case elaborated above, the score allotted is :

  • Eye-opening to speech—3
  • Inappropriate words—3
  • Extensor response of the upper limb in response to painful stimuli—2

Patients scoring a GCS of 3 or 4 have an 85% chance of dying or remaining vegetative.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room after he was brutally beaten during a mugging incident. He is unresponsive even to painful stimuli and is apneic; however, he does have a pulse. Which of the following clinical findings would exclude a diagnosis of brain death?
questions.solution:
Constricted pupils would rule out brain death.

Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all cerebral function with the preservation of cardiac activity and maintenance of respiratory and somatic function by artificial means.

In brain death, the pupils are usually midsized or maybe dilated. However, constricted pupils are not seen. 

The diagnosis of brain death should be confirmed with the following clinical findings:

  • Absent brain-originating motor response, including response to pain stimulus above the neck or other brain-originating movements (eg, seizures, decerebrate or decorticate posturing)
  • Unresponsiveness to any stimuli
  • Brainstem damage, as evidenced by dilated or mid-sized pupils without light reaction
  • Absent corneal, gag, and oculovestibular reflexes
  • Absent sucking or rooting reflexes
  • Absent cough with tracheal suctioning
  • Apnea, indicating medullary destruction
  • The heart rate should be invariant and does not accelerate to atropine

questions.text: The family of an ICU patient who is in a coma has given consent for organ donation. An apnea test is performed. Lack of respiratory effort at what arterial pCO2 level will aid in confirming brain death?
questions.solution:
To declare brain death, apnea is confirmed if no respiratory effort has been observed in the presence of arterial pCO2 levels of ≥60 mmHg (apnea test is positive).

Destruction of the medulla leads to complete and irreversible apnea. Demonstration that apnea is due to medullary damage requires that the PCO2 be high enough to stimulate respiration during a test of spontaneous breathing. 

An apnea test is conducted to confirm that there is no respiratory effort in the presence of a sufficiently elevated arterial PCO2. Apnea testing can be done safely by the use of preoxygenation with 100% oxygen prior to and following removal of the ventilator. CO2 tension increases ~0.3–0.4 kPa/min (2–3 mmHg/min) during apnea.

questions.text: Clinical criteria for brain death include all except:
questions.solution:
Clinical criteria for brain death does not include absent spinal cord reflexes. Deep tendon reflexes/spinal cord reflexes may be present in brain death as the spinal cord is intact.

Criteria for brain death:

  • Coma - Deep, unresponsiveness to noxious stimuli
  • Absence of brainstem reflexes - Pupillary, oculocephalic, corneal, gag reflex, etc.
  • Apnea - Absence of spontaneous respiration at arterial pCO2 tension of at least 50–60mm Hg
